content.html:
What do you think about allowing Shift+Return to add newlines? I kind-of like it so I can add whitespace to large variable definitions so they are easier to read.

It appears to be as easy as modifying the keyPressEvent of the Editor.

def keyPressEvent(self, event):
    if event.key() == QtCore.Qt.Key_Return and event.modifiers() == QtCore.Qt.ShiftModifier:
        return QtWidgets.QTextEdit.keyPressEvent(self, event)
    elif event.key() in [QtCore.Qt.Key_Enter, QtCore.Qt.Key_Return]:
        event.accept()
        self.close()
        return
    return QtWidgets.QTextEdit.keyPressEvent(self, event)

content.raw:
I was able to reproduce something similar but not quite identical. Hitting enter or tab alone did not do anything, I needed to hit tab again. Navigation would normally move to the expansion column, but runmanager had special-cased that column not to be tabbed to, since you’re unlikely to need to edit it often and probably don’t want to mess with it. So tab would skip that column and the next thing to be focused would be … the close button. So it would interpret tapping space as hitting the close button.

I’ve removed the special-casing, because I think it is causing more confusion than it is worth. And with increased visibility of what cell is selected , hopefully it will be obvious that you’re no longer in the tableview. I’ve also made the close button not hold focus, so that you can’t tab to focus it in any case.

content.raw:
I’ll wait, there’s no rush. The changes were pretty invasive, so more testing is a good idea.

One thing I’ve noticed is that automatic sorting of rows every time something changes is actually working after the change to a QTableView for the globals. I hadn’t noticed it, but sorting was _not_ working when it was a TreeView. There is a lot of code for managing sorting in runmanager, and I can’t imagine having written all that in the initial Qt port if it didn’t ever work, so I’m guessing this stopped working at some point - perhaps with Qt5.

But it turns out that automatic sorting is super annoying! Things jump around randomly and you end up selecting cells you didn’t intend to when clicking on cells after editing other cells.

So maybe I’ll do it in a separate PR, but I’m wondering if we should just remove most of the sorting code. The user can still cause a sort to happen by clicking on the headers, but I would want to change it so that no automatic sorting would be done when cell contents change. Globals will be loaded from disk ordered by name, so there’ll be that initial sorting but that’s it. There will still need to be a bit of code to make sure “add new global” sorts to the end of the list regardless of sort order \(I thought this used to be the case, but apparently not anymore\), but otherwise this would be removing pretty much all of the sorting code.

Yes, I switched it to the monospace font for the name and value, since they are both code - well one is a variable name and the other is code, at least. This helps with indentation for a multi-line value, though that’s not as relevant for the name. I think it makes a lot of sense for the value to be monospace, and I’m less adamant about the name. I guess I wish the mono font was _slightly_ bolder, that annoys me. But making it actually bold looks way too bold. Does it look any better to you if the font size is bumped up by one \(add UBUNTU\_FONT\_SIZE \+= 1 at the top of `__main__.py`\)?

It looks like I erroneously added a bit of extra vertical padding compared to what I intended. I’ve now changed it to have the same row width as before. It’s tricky because before it was just a fixed width and now it’s the item’s width plus some padding, and the item’s width even when it’s one line of text only depends on whether it has an icon. So it ended up with a few extra pixels but they’re gone now!

I could probably make the <add new global> item selectable via keyboard without much effort - we’re already hooking into the arrow keys in a place in the code where this would make sense to handle.

I could change <click to add global> to the same monospace font so it is more obviously part of the column, excluding it was intentional but I don’t mind either way.

Increasing the size of the expansion column to the size of ‘outer’ sounds good, I’ll give it a shot.

pullrequest.title: Word-wrapping in treeviews and item views, adapted from David Meyer's implementation.

content.raw:
Ah, I see. I’ve now changed it to use the default font size, so it is now just not specifying the font size. This means it’s bigger on Linux and smaller on Windows and should fit in with the surrounding fonts.

I also changed the semantics of how the cell sizes are calculated again, this should improve the padding situation a bit more. Now it’s simply a 22px minimum row size, but if the cell’s contents are already larger than that, then it’s whatever its contents' size is plus 6px padding.

Happy to bundle a different mono font if you have a preference - though I’d rather bundle something so it’s the same everywhere rather than use system fonts, and if we bundle one then it has to have a license compatible with that, and ideally be a font with good unicode coverage since we’ll use it in the OutputBox too. The Ubuntu font is pretty comprehensive when it comes to unicode. Inconsolata is pretty popular but has poor unicode coverage, and BitStream Vera Sans Mono, which is my goto when Ubuntu isn’t around has good unicode support but the same dotted zero you’re not a fan of. Source Code Pro is pretty popular and comprehensive, but again with the dotted zero.

Roboto Mono Regular checks all the boxes though. But testing it it appears a bit larger at the default size so we’d have to tweak it.

But I’d prefer not to change the font or make it cusomisable since it would be some work bundling it and tweaking font sizes for not much gain.

Let me know if you’re happy with everything other than personal preferences about fonts! \(I mean, we can keep talking about that as well, but let me know if there are other remaining issues\)
